rev.diff:
Line 67: Line 67:
The read-only nature of CDs and DVDs means that user data cannot be stored with the operating system, but must be written to some other device (such as a USB flash drive or an installed hard drive) if any is to be kept. Temporary operating system data is usually kept solely in [[random access memory|RAM]].
The read-only nature of CDs and DVDs means that user data cannot be stored with the operating system, but must be written to some other device (such as a USB flash drive or an installed hard drive) if any is to be kept. Temporary operating system data is usually kept solely in [[random access memory|RAM]].
â
The portablility is advantageous for applications such as demonstrations, borrowing someone else's computer, rescue operations, and as installation media for a standard distribution. Many popular distributions come in both "Live" and conventional forms (the conventional form being a network or removable media image which is intended to be used for installation only). This includes [[SUSE]], [[Ubuntu]], [[Mepis]], and [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]]. Some distributions, such as [[Knoppix]] and [[Dyne:bolic]], are designed primarily for Live CD or Live DVD use.
+
The portablility is advantageous for applications such as demonstrations, borrowing someone else's computer, rescue operations, and as installation media for a standard distribution. Many popular distributions come in both "Live" and conventional forms (the conventional form being a network or removable media image which is intended to be used for installation only). This includes [[SUSE]], [[Ubuntu]], [[Mepis]], and [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]]. Some distributions, such as [[Knoppix]] and [[Dyne:bolic]], are designed primarily for Live CD or Live DVD use.
==Examples==
==Examples==
Line 77: Line 77:
* [[CentOS]], a distribution derived from the same sources used by Red Hat, maintained by a dedicated volunteer community of developers with both 100% Red Hat - compatible versions and an upgraded version that is not always 100% upstream compatible
* [[CentOS]], a distribution derived from the same sources used by Red Hat, maintained by a dedicated volunteer community of developers with both 100% Red Hat - compatible versions and an upgraded version that is not always 100% upstream compatible
* [[Debian]], a non-commercial distribution maintained by a volunteer developer community with a strong commitment to free software principles
* [[Debian]], a non-commercial distribution maintained by a volunteer developer community with a strong commitment to free software principles
â
* [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]] which is a community distribution sponsored by [[Red Hat]]
+
* [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]] which is a community distribution sponsored by [[Red Hat]]
* [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]], a distribution targeted at [[power user]]s, known for its [[FreeBSD Ports]]-like automated system for compiling applications from source code
* [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]], a distribution targeted at [[power user]]s, known for its [[FreeBSD Ports]]-like automated system for compiling applications from source code
* [[Knoppix]], a [[Live CD]] distribution that runs completely from [[removable media]] and without installation to a hard disk
* [[Knoppix]], a [[Live CD]] distribution that runs completely from [[removable media]] and without installation to a hard disk
Line 84: Line 84:
* [[openSUSE]], originally derived from Slackware, sponsored by the company [[Novell]]
* [[openSUSE]], originally derived from Slackware, sponsored by the company [[Novell]]
* [[PCLinuxOS]] which is the number 5 distribution on [[DistroWatch]] as of August 9, 2008. [[PCLinuxOS]] is derived from [[Mandriva Linux|Mandriva]]
* [[PCLinuxOS]] which is the number 5 distribution on [[DistroWatch]] as of August 9, 2008. [[PCLinuxOS]] is derived from [[Mandriva Linux|Mandriva]]
â
* [[Red Hat Enterprise Linux]], which is a derivative of [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]] maintained and commercially supported by [[Red Hat]]
+
* [[Red Hat Enterprise Linux]], which is a derivative of [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]] maintained and commercially supported by [[Red Hat]]
* [[Slackware]], one of the first Linux distributions, founded in 1993, and since then actively maintained by [[Patrick J. Volkerding]]
* [[Slackware]], one of the first Linux distributions, founded in 1993, and since then actively maintained by [[Patrick J. Volkerding]]
* [[Ubuntu]], a newly popular desktop distribution maintained by [[Canonical Ltd|Canonical]] that is derived from Debian.
* [[Ubuntu]], a newly popular desktop distribution maintained by [[Canonical Ltd|Canonical]] that is derived from Debian.
Line 123: Line 123:
*On embedded devices, Linux is typically held in the device's [[firmware]] and may or may not be consumer-accessible.
*On embedded devices, Linux is typically held in the device's [[firmware]] and may or may not be consumer-accessible.

[[Anaconda installer|Anaconda]], one of the more popular installers, is used by [[Red Hat Enterprise Linux]], [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]] and other distributions to simplify the installation process.
